habitat_description:
This parthenogenetic whiptail lizard occupies an area along the Rio Grande River in southern Texas that extends into Tamaulipas, Mexico. It is found from Brownsville to Del Rio, but also in areas further away from the Rio Grande River (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Paulissen and walker 1998; Walker 1987). Morphotypes of this whiptail are found in croplands, hedgerows, grassland habitats, chaparral, and desert shrubland (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999). 

Paulissen (1999) reported abundant numbers of both morphotypes near Los Ebanos, Hidalgo County, Texas. The authors also described morphotype LAR-A, former Cnemidophorus laredoensis, to preferably occur on both sides of the Rio Grande River. This morphotype can be found from Laredo and Nuevo Laredo to south-central Hidalgo County, Texas. Also found in smaller numbers further from the Rio Grande River in Dimmit, LaSalle, and Starr Counties. In a more disjunct distribution, morphotype LAR-B occurs from Del Rio, Val Verde County well into Mexico along the Rio Grande. Also found in northern Webb County, and south central Starr County. 

Short and tall grasses and weeds, mesquite, bunchgrass, as well as ecotonal thorn scrub. Can also be found along dense vegetation and disturbed sandy/loamy soil areas.
